photo
Prediction of the value of a (dependent) variable, based on the value of another existing (independent) variable One or more independent variables that can most accurately predict the value of the dependent variable are used to estimate the coefficients of the linear equation. Finds the specific variables that are significant for predicting the values of the dependent variable Determines how well does these independent variables impact the dependent variable
photo
We use a regression line which has an equation of the form y = mx + b, where X is the explanatory variable and Y is the dependent variable. The slope of the line is b, and a is the intercept (the value of y when x = 0). Linear regression fits a straight line or surface that minimizes the discrepancies between predicted and actual output values.

Simple Linear Regression

Ex. Predicting the weight of other people having their height as the main basis for prediction We can plot the height of an individual through the years as the function for the body weight of that individual (dependent variable). We can see a linear relationship between the variables
Using the regression line equation y = mx + b, we can predict the weight of an individual given his/her height. Ex. Height of Person A = 70 inches To predict the weight of Person a, use the equation y = mx + b, y = Weight of Person A m = Slope of the line x = Height of Person A b = Intercept (Value of y when x = 0)
From this example, we are examining how strong the relationship between one independent variable (height) and the dependent variable (weight). If the only basis we can use for a linear regression for this example is height alone, we can easily conclude that the points would lie near the regression line. However, height is not the only factor/variable that affects the weight of an individual. Considering the other variables that really affects the weight of a person would result to the points in a regression line to be more scattered around the regression line.
